channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: International Criminal Court Drops Case Against Kenya’s William Ruto
item.description: Mr. Ruto, Kenya’s deputy president, faced charges of crimes against humanity in connection with deadly violence after the 2007 elections.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: MARLISE SIMONS and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: The deputy president of Kenya, William Ruto, right, at the International Criminal Court in The Hague in 2013.

item.title: Panama Papers Scandal Brings Down Iceland’s Prime Minister
item.description: The departure of Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson is the most prominent fallout from the leaked papers. Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain is also battling revelations that involve his family.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and STEPHEN CASTLE
item.media:description: Prime Minister Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson of Iceland was surrounded by members of the news media as he left a meeting with President Olafur Ragnar Grimsson in Reykjavik on Tuesday.

item.title: Jacob Zuma Beats Back Impeachment Drive in South Africa
item.description: The opposition party motion to impeach Mr. Zuma, prompted by a long-running corruption case, had been given little chance of success.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI
item.media:description: President Jacob G. Zuma of South Africa answering lawmakers’ questions in Cape Town last month.

item.title: Raw Data: To Beat Go Champion, Google’s Program Needed a Human Army
item.description: Without the multitude of minds that created a program capable of beating a Go game master, the contest would have been a no-go.
item.dc:creator: GEORGE JOHNSON
item.media:description: Lee Se-dol, a professional Go player from South Korea, was smiling amid other players despite losing four of five games against a Google computer program called AlphaGo.

item.title: India Puts Curbs on Foreign-Funded Health Consultants
item.description: For decades, India has turned to international aid agencies to fill gaps in its health care system. Now Narendra Modi’s government is cracking down.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: A doctor looked at an X-ray of a patient with tuberculosis at a hospital in Bhopal, India, last month.

item.title: The ‘Panama Papers’: Here’s What We Know
item.description: The documents name international politicians, business leaders and celebrities in a web of unseemly financial transactions, according to news articles.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Sigmundur David Gunnlaugsson addressing the Icelandic Parliament in Reykjavik on Monday. He offered his resignation as prime minister on Tuesday.

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Chappatte on Sending Migrants to Turkey
item.description: Earlier this week, the European Union started deporting migrants from Greece as part of the deal worked out with Turkey.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: PATRICK CHAPPATTE

item.title: U.N. Strives for Transparency in Picking New Secretary General
item.description: While the United Nations is trying to make the selection of a new secretary general more transparent, the world powers are, as usual, expected to exert undue influence over the process itself.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Letter From America: Momentum for Pacific Trade Deal Sapped in Election Year
item.description: The Trans-Pacific Partnership, President Obama’s top remaining priority before Congress, has taken a serious beating during the presidential campaign.
item.dc:creator: JOHN HARWOOD
item.media:description: President Obama delivering remarks after a meeting with present and former national security leaders on the Trans-Pacific Partnership trade deal at the White House in November.

item.title: World Briefing: Saudi Police Colonel Is Killed and ISIS Claims Responsibility
item.description: The colonel was shot dead near the capital of Riyadh, the latest attack in the kingdom to be claimed by the Islamic State.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Here’s What We Know About the ‘Panama Papers’
item.description: The documents name international politicians, business leaders and celebrities in a web of unseemly financial transactions, according to news articles.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:description: Skyscrapers and residential buildings lining the beach in Miami. A report by the International Consortium of Investigative Journalists indicated possible connections between condo purchases in South Florida and money laundering.

item.title: Air France Faces Backlash Over Veil Policy on Route to Iran
item.description: The airline instructed female employees to wear conservative attire while working in Tehran, prompting a union to accuse the company of “an attack on women.”
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.media:credit: Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Air France has faced anger over a memo calling on its female employees to wear veils while in Iran.

item.title: Rebels in Syria Shoot Down Government Fighter Jet
item.description: The pilot was captured after he parachuted to the ground, though exactly how the plane was brought down was unclear.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD and HWAIDA SAAD
item.media:description: Syrian rebel fighters and civilians surrounded the wreckage of a Syrian government fighter jet shot down in northern Syria on Tuesday.

item.title: Former Top Military Official in China Took ‘Huge’ Bribes, Inquiry Finds
item.description: Military prosecutors are said to have found that Guo Boxiong, who retired in 2012, took bribes in exchange for helping officers win promotions or transfers.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Guo Boxiong in 2009. His prosecution illustrates the lengths that President Xi Jinping is taking to purge the People’s Liberation Army of corruption.

item.title: Zika Forest Journal: In a Remote Ugandan Lab, Encounters With Zika and Mosquitoes Decades Ago
item.description: A forested site where science and exploration overlapped in the discovery of numerous viruses is today a little patch of forest, but research into the Zika virus continues.
item.dc:creator: JOSH KRON
item.media:description: Researchers from the Uganda Virus Research Institute carrying insect traps in Zika Forest.

item.title: Myanmar Approves New Title for Aung San Suu Kyi, Rankling Military
item.description: Some members of Parliament denounced the measure, which could give her authority exceeding the president’s, as an unconstitutional power grab.
item.dc:creator: WAI MOE and RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nyein Chan Naing
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi and Senior Gen. Min Aung Hlaing, the armed forces chief, in Naypyidaw, the capital, last week. Ms. Aung San Suu Kyi will become “state counselor” under a measure approved on Tuesday by Parliament’s lower house.

item.title: Despite Several Blows to Shabab, Worries Persist About Their Resilience
item.description: The recent strikes against the militant group in Somalia will “hurt them, no doubt,” an analyst said, “but they tend to regenerate.”
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:description: Shabab fighters during military exercises on the outskirts of Mogadishu, Somalia, in 2011. The Pentagon said last month it had killed 150 militants in an airstrike.

item.title: North Korea Is Able to Mount Nuclear Warhead on Missile, South Says
item.description: An official added that South Korea had no evidence that the North had deployed such nuclear-tipped Rodong missiles, which could reach all of the South and most of Japan.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Sentry posts belonging to North Korea, in the background, and the South on opposite sides of the border.

item.title: Sinosphere: China Censors Mentions of ‘Panama Papers’ Leaks
item.description: The top censored phrases monitored on Weibo all appeared to be related to the leaks: tax evasion, file, leaked, Putin and company.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: The leaks showed that Li Xiaolin, the daughter of the former premier Li Peng, and her husband, Liu Zhiyuan, owned a foundation based in Liechtenstein that in turn owned a company in the British Virgin Islands, Cofic Investments.

item.title: Indonesia’s Orangutans Suffer as Fires Rage and Businesses Grow
item.description: The blazes, an annual occurrence where farmers clear land by burning it, often for palm oil plantations, have led to the relocation and even deaths of some of the apes.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Kemal Jufri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Orphaned orangutans at a rehabilitation center in the Indonesian province of Central Kalimantan.
